name: Clone a Switch using Action Batches

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.example:
[
  [
    {
      "number": 1,
      "name": "My switch port",
      "tags": "tag1 tag2",
      "enabled": true,
      "poeEnabled": true,
      "type": "access",
      "vlan": 10,
      "voiceVlan": 20,
      "isolationEnabled": false,
      "rstpEnabled": true,
      "stpGuard": "disabled",
      "accessPolicyNumber": "1234",
      "linkNegotiation": "Auto negotiate",
      "portScheduleId": "1234",
      "udld": "Alert only",
      "macWhitelist": [
        "34:56:fe:ce:8e:b0",
        "34:56:fe:ce:8e:b1"
      ],
      "stickyMacWhitelist": [
        "34:56:fe:ce:8e:b0",
        "34:56:fe:ce:8e:b1"
      ],
      "stickyMacWhitelistLimit": 5
    }
  ]
]

filteredMethods.summary: Update the attributes of a device

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Blink the LEDs on a device

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The timespan for which LLDP and CDP information will be fetched. Must be in seconds and less than or equal to a month (2592000 seconds). LLDP and CDP information is sent to the Meraki dashboard every 10 minutes. In instances where this LLDP and CDP information matches an existing entry in the Meraki dashboard, the data is updated once every two hours. Meraki recommends querying LLDP and CDP information at an interval slightly greater than two hours, to ensure that unchanged CDP / LLDP information can be queried consistently.
filteredMethods.summary: List LLDP and CDP information for a device

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The beginning of the timespan for the data. The maximum lookback period is 365 days from today.

The end of the timespan for the data. t1 can be a maximum of 31 days after t0.

The timespan for which the information will be fetched. If specifying timespan, do not specify parameters t0 and t1. The value must be in seconds and be less than or equal to 31 days. The default is 1 day.

The time resolution in seconds for returned data. The valid resolutions are: 60, 600, 3600, 86400. The default is 60.

The WAN uplink used to obtain the requested stats. Valid uplinks are wan1, wan2, cellular. The default is wan1.

The destination IP used to obtain the requested stats. This is required.
filteredMethods.summary: Get the uplink loss percentage and latency in milliseconds for a wired network device.

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Return the performance score for a single device. Only primary MX devices supported. If no data is available a 204 error code is returned.

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
Parameters
Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Return the uplink information for a device.

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The number of entries per page returned. Acceptable range is 3 - 1000. Default is 1000.

A token used by the server to indicate the start of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.

A token used by the server to indicate the end of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.
filteredMethods.example:
[
  {
    "name": "My AP",
    "lat": 37.4180951010362,
    "lng": -122.098531723022,
    "address": "1600 Pennsylvania Ave",
    "notes": "My AP's note",
    "tags": " recently-added ",
    "networkId": "N_24329156",
    "serial": "Q234-ABCD-5678",
    "model": "MR34",
    "mac": "00:11:22:33:44:55",
    "lanIp": "1.2.3.4"
  }
]
